classes.title: MASC51.
classes.subtitle: First Year Seminar: Global Warming: Science, Social Impacts, Solutions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Students will examine evidence that human activity has caused global warming, investigate scientists' ability to predict climate change, and discuss the political and social dimensions of global climate change.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC52.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Living with Our Oceans and Atmosphere.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Students will examine evidence that human activity has caused global warming, investigate scientists' ability to predict climate change, and discuss the political and social dimensions of global climate change.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC52.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Living with Our Oceans and Atmosphere.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Modern theories of changing weather, severe weather events, oceanic hazards, interactions between the oceans and atmosphere, and changes that are linked to human activity.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC53.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: The Ends of the Earth: Polar Oceanography and Exploration.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Modern theories of changing weather, severe weather events, oceanic hazards, interactions between the oceans and atmosphere, and changes that are linked to human activity.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC53.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: The Ends of the Earth: Polar Oceanography and Exploration.  3 Credits.
classes.description: What explains the "pull of the poles"? This seminar combines a modern survey of polar oceanography with historical views of early polar explorations, as reported by the explorers themselves.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC55.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Change in the Coastal Ocean.  3 Credits.
classes.description: What explains the "pull of the poles"? This seminar combines a modern survey of polar oceanography with historical views of early polar explorations, as reported by the explorers themselves.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC55.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Change in the Coastal Ocean.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course provides an opportunity to explore changes in marine and closely linked terrestrial environments caused by the interactions of fascinating oceanographic processes. Introductory presentations and discussions will focus on published works of active marine scientists who combine disciplinary training with knowledge and skills from other fields.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC57.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: From "The Sound of Music" to "The Perfect Storm.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course provides an opportunity to explore changes in marine and closely linked terrestrial environments caused by the interactions of fascinating oceanographic processes. Introductory presentations and discussions will focus on published works of active marine scientists who combine disciplinary training with knowledge and skills from other fields.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC57.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: From "The Sound of Music" to "The Perfect Storm.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Students will develop the conceptual framework necessary to understand waves of any kind, starting from laboratory observations. Honors version availableGen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�63.

classes.title: MASC58.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Connections to the Sea: The Challenges Faced by Using and Living near Coastal In.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Students will develop the conceptual framework necessary to understand waves of any kind, starting from laboratory observations. Honors version availableGen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�63.

classes.title: MASC58.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Connections to the Sea: The Challenges Faced by Using and Living near Coastal In.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores the natural history of several inlets, impact of human intervention, and political/policy challenges faced; includes several group projects/presentations and a field trip to a coastal inlet.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC59.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Extreme Microorganisms: Pushing the Limits of Life on Earth and Beyond.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores the natural history of several inlets, impact of human intervention, and political/policy challenges faced; includes several group projects/presentations and a field trip to a coastal inlet.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC59.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Extreme Microorganisms: Pushing the Limits of Life on Earth and Beyond.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This seminar focuses on some of the most extreme microorganisms on the planet, microorganisms that thrive without oxygen, under high temperatures (e.g., in pressurized water above the boiling point), and under chemical stress factors (high sulfide and heavy metal concentrations) that were once thought to be incompatible with life.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC89.
classes.subtitle: First -Year Seminar: Special Topics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This seminar focuses on some of the most extreme microorganisms on the planet, microorganisms that thrive without oxygen, under high temperatures (e.g., in pressurized water above the boiling point), and under chemical stress factors (high sulfide and heavy metal concentrations) that were once thought to be incompatible with life.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC89.
classes.subtitle: First -Year Seminar: Special Topics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics course.  Content will vary each semester.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC101
classes.subtitle: The Marine Environment.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics course.  Content will vary each semester.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC101
classes.subtitle: The Marine Environment.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Introduction to marine sciences emphasizing physical, chemical, biological, and geological phenomenon in oceanic and coastal environments. Human use of, and impact on, marine resources. Science majors should take MASC�401. Students may not receive credit for both MASC�101 and MASC�401.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�103.

classes.title: MASC108
classes.subtitle: Climate and Energy Transitions: Understanding the Forecasts.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Introduction to marine sciences emphasizing physical, chemical, biological, and geological phenomenon in oceanic and coastal environments. Human use of, and impact on, marine resources. Science majors should take MASC�401. Students may not receive credit for both MASC�101 and MASC�401.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�103.

classes.title: MASC108
classes.subtitle: Climate and Energy Transitions: Understanding the Forecasts.  4 Credits.
classes.description: This course examines uncertainties in projecting future fossil fuel consumption and impact on global climate by quantifying how effectively alternative power-generation and energy-storage technologies can scale to meet needs in developing and developed nations, and by understanding past and present climates.Gen Ed: PX, GL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�108, PHYS�108.

classes.title: MASC190
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Sciences.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course examines uncertainties in projecting future fossil fuel consumption and impact on global climate by quantifying how effectively alternative power-generation and energy-storage technologies can scale to meet needs in developing and developed nations, and by understanding past and present climates.Gen Ed: PX, GL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�108, PHYS�108.

classes.title: MASC190
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Sciences.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An undergraduate seminar course that is designed to be a participatory intellectual adventure on an advanced, emergent, and stimulating topic within a selected discipline in marine sciences.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC220
classes.subtitle: North Carolina Estuaries: Environmental Processes and Problems.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An undergraduate seminar course that is designed to be a participatory intellectual adventure on an advanced, emergent, and stimulating topic within a selected discipline in marine sciences.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC220
classes.subtitle: North Carolina Estuaries: Environmental Processes and Problems.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Natural processes and human impacts on estuarine systems using the Neuse River estuary as a case study. Course includes one week of intensive field work based at the Institute of Marine Sciences. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for ENEC�222.Gen Ed: PX, EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�220.

classes.title: MASC223
classes.subtitle: Geology of Beaches and Coasts.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Natural processes and human impacts on estuarine systems using the Neuse River estuary as a case study. Course includes one week of intensive field work based at the Institute of Marine Sciences. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for ENEC�222.Gen Ed: PX, EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�220.

classes.title: MASC223
classes.subtitle: Geology of Beaches and Coasts.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, one introductory geology course numbered below GEOL�202, except first-year seminar. Introduction to coastal processes, including waves, tidal currents, tectonics, climate, and human activity, and their influence on barrier islands, beaches, dunes, marshes, and estuaries. Involves a field trip to the Outer Banks of North Carolina.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�223.

classes.title: MASC310
classes.subtitle: Our Changing Planet: Science, Social Impacts, Solutions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, one introductory geology course numbered below GEOL�202, except first-year seminar. Introduction to coastal processes, including waves, tidal currents, tectonics, climate, and human activity, and their influence on barrier islands, beaches, dunes, marshes, and estuaries. Involves a field trip to the Outer Banks of North Carolina.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�223.

classes.title: MASC310
classes.subtitle: Our Changing Planet: Science, Social Impacts, Solutions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An overview of the scientific basis for global warming, current and future impacts on society, options for mitigation and adaptation, and the role of politics and the media.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC312
classes.subtitle: From the Equator to the Poles: Case Studies in Global Environmental Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An overview of the scientific basis for global warming, current and future impacts on society, options for mitigation and adaptation, and the role of politics and the media.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC312
classes.subtitle: From the Equator to the Poles: Case Studies in Global Environmental Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Case studies in environmental change, highlighting human and environmental dynamics in terrestrial and marine ecosystems on multiple spatial and temporal scales. Includes active-learning modules, group presentations, writing assignments.Gen Ed: SS, GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC314
classes.subtitle: Earth Systems in a Changing World.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Case studies in environmental change, highlighting human and environmental dynamics in terrestrial and marine ecosystems on multiple spatial and temporal scales. Includes active-learning modules, group presentations, writing assignments.Gen Ed: SS, GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC314
classes.subtitle: Earth Systems in a Changing World.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course presents an integrated view of our planet, how it evolved during the past, why it has changed (and continues to change), and what makes Earth a habitable planet.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC316
classes.subtitle: Coastal Environmental Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course presents an integrated view of our planet, how it evolved during the past, why it has changed (and continues to change), and what makes Earth a habitable planet.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC316
classes.subtitle: Coastal Environmental Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An exploration of the large-scale evolution of coastal environments, including relevance of geologic setting, wave and sediment transport processes, the evolution of beach and barrier island morphology, and issues of coastal environmental management.Requisites: Prerequisite, GEOL�101 or MASC�101 or MASC�401; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�310, ENEC�310.

classes.title: MASC352
classes.subtitle: Marine Fisheries Ecology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An exploration of the large-scale evolution of coastal environments, including relevance of geologic setting, wave and sediment transport processes, the evolution of beach and barrier island morphology, and issues of coastal environmental management.Requisites: Prerequisite, GEOL�101 or MASC�101 or MASC�401; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�310, ENEC�310.

classes.title: MASC352
classes.subtitle: Marine Fisheries Ecology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Gives students a foundation in population biology and the ecological processes that influence populations of economically important fish and shellfish. Students will gain practical quantitative skills including statistical analyses, model development, and data visualization. Familiarity with introductory statistics concepts is preferred but not necessary.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�101, 401, or ENEC�202.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�352.

classes.title: MASC390
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Sciences (for Undergraduates).  1-4 Credits.
classes.description: Gives students a foundation in population biology and the ecological processes that influence populations of economically important fish and shellfish. Students will gain practical quantitative skills including statistical analyses, model development, and data visualization. Familiarity with introductory statistics concepts is preferred but not necessary.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�101, 401, or ENEC�202.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�352.

classes.title: MASC390
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Sciences (for Undergraduates).  1-4 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics in marine sciences for undergraduate students.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 3 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC395
classes.subtitle: Undergraduate Research in Marine Sciences.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics in marine sciences for undergraduate students.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 3 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC395
classes.subtitle: Undergraduate Research in Marine Sciences.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of a faculty research director. Directed readings with laboratory study on a selected topic.Gen Ed: EE- Mentored Research.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 8 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC396
classes.subtitle: Independent Study in Marine Sciences.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of a faculty research director. Directed readings with laboratory study on a selected topic.Gen Ed: EE- Mentored Research.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 8 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC396
classes.subtitle: Independent Study in Marine Sciences.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Directed readings on a selected topic.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC401
classes.subtitle: Oceanography.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Directed readings on a selected topic.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC401
classes.subtitle: Oceanography.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, major in a natural science or two courses in natural sciences. Studies origin of ocean basins, seawater chemistry and dynamics, biological communities, sedimentary record, and oceanographic history. Term paper. Students lacking science background should see MASC�101. Students may not receive credit for both MASC�101 and MASC�401.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�350, ENVR�417, GEOL�403.

classes.title: MASC410
classes.subtitle: Earth Processes in Environmental Systems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, major in a natural science or two courses in natural sciences. Studies origin of ocean basins, seawater chemistry and dynamics, biological communities, sedimentary record, and oceanographic history. Term paper. Students lacking science background should see MASC�101. Students may not receive credit for both MASC�101 and MASC�401.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�350, ENVR�417, GEOL�403.

classes.title: MASC410
classes.subtitle: Earth Processes in Environmental Systems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of geological and related Earth systems sciences are applied to analyses of environmental phenomena. The link between the lithosphere and other environmental compartments is explored through case studies of environmental issues. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102, GEOL�200, MATH�231, and PHYS�115 or 119; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�410, GEOL�410.

classes.title: MASC411
classes.subtitle: Oceanic Processes in Environmental Systems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of geological and related Earth systems sciences are applied to analyses of environmental phenomena. The link between the lithosphere and other environmental compartments is explored through case studies of environmental issues. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102, GEOL�200, MATH�231, and PHYS�115 or 119; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�410, GEOL�410.

classes.title: MASC411
classes.subtitle: Oceanic Processes in Environmental Systems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of analysis of the ocean, coast, and estuarine environments and the processes that control these environments are applied to the analysis of environmental phenomena. Case studies of environmental issues. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOL�101, CHEM�102, ENEC�222, MATH�231, PHYS�115 or 119; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�411, GEOL�411.

classes.title: MASC415
classes.subtitle: Environmental Systems Modeling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of analysis of the ocean, coast, and estuarine environments and the processes that control these environments are applied to the analysis of environmental phenomena. Case studies of environmental issues. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, BIOL�101, CHEM�102, ENEC�222, MATH�231, PHYS�115 or 119; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�411, GEOL�411.

classes.title: MASC415
classes.subtitle: Environmental Systems Modeling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores principles and strategies for studying environmental phenomena, and presents methods for developing explanatory and predictive models of environmental systems, e.g., predator-prey, estuaries, greenhouse gases, and ecosystem material cycles.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�383; pre- or corequisite, PHYS�115 or 118, and COMP�116.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�415, GEOL�415.

classes.title: MASC432
classes.subtitle: Major World Rivers and Global Change: From Mountains to the Sea.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores principles and strategies for studying environmental phenomena, and presents methods for developing explanatory and predictive models of environmental systems, e.g., predator-prey, estuaries, greenhouse gases, and ecosystem material cycles.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�383; pre- or corequisite, PHYS�115 or 118, and COMP�116.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�415, GEOL�415.

classes.title: MASC432
classes.subtitle: Major World Rivers and Global Change: From Mountains to the Sea.  3 Credits.
classes.description: What are the linkages between rivers and global change? This course examines the hydrological, geological and biogeochemical processes that control material flux from land to the oceans via rivers.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC433
classes.subtitle: Wetland Hydrology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: What are the linkages between rivers and global change? This course examines the hydrological, geological and biogeochemical processes that control material flux from land to the oceans via rivers.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC433
classes.subtitle: Wetland Hydrology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Study of wetland ecosystems with particular emphasis on hydrological functioning, the transition from terrestrial to aquatic systems, wetlands as filtration systems, and exchange between wetlands and other environments.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�433.

classes.title: MASC434
classes.subtitle: Blue Carbon and Coastal Environments.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Study of wetland ecosystems with particular emphasis on hydrological functioning, the transition from terrestrial to aquatic systems, wetlands as filtration systems, and exchange between wetlands and other environments.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�433.

classes.title: MASC434
classes.subtitle: Blue Carbon and Coastal Environments.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor is required. Readings and discussions about processes in traditional "Blue Carbon" environments (marshes, sea grass beds, and mangroves) and an exploration of carbon burial in other coastal ecosystems such as floodplains and oyster reefs.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC440
classes.subtitle: Marine Ecology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor is required. Readings and discussions about processes in traditional "Blue Carbon" environments (marshes, sea grass beds, and mangroves) and an exploration of carbon burial in other coastal ecosystems such as floodplains and oyster reefs.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC440
classes.subtitle: Marine Ecology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Survey of the ecological processes that structure marine communities in a range of coastal habitats. Course emphasizes experimental approaches to addressing basic and applied problems in marine systems.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOL�201 or 475.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�462.

classes.title: MASC441
classes.subtitle: Marine Physiological Ecology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Survey of the ecological processes that structure marine communities in a range of coastal habitats. Course emphasizes experimental approaches to addressing basic and applied problems in marine systems.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOL�201 or 475.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�462.

classes.title: MASC441
classes.subtitle: Marine Physiological Ecology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course introduces students to the physiological, morphological, and behavioral factors employed by marine organisms to cope with their physical environment. Emphasis will be placed on the response of marine organisms to environmental factors such as seawater temperature, light, water salinity, ocean acidification, etc.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�441.

classes.title: MASC442
classes.subtitle: Marine Biology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course introduces students to the physiological, morphological, and behavioral factors employed by marine organisms to cope with their physical environment. Emphasis will be placed on the response of marine organisms to environmental factors such as seawater temperature, light, water salinity, ocean acidification, etc.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�441.

classes.title: MASC442
classes.subtitle: Marine Biology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, BIOL�201 or 475. A survey of plants and animals that live in the sea: characteristics of marine habitats, organisms, and the ecosystems will be emphasized. Marine environment, the organisms involved, and the ecological systems that sustain them.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�457.

classes.title: MASC443
classes.subtitle: Marine Microbiology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, BIOL�201 or 475. A survey of plants and animals that live in the sea: characteristics of marine habitats, organisms, and the ecosystems will be emphasized. Marine environment, the organisms involved, and the ecological systems that sustain them.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�457.

classes.title: MASC443
classes.subtitle: Marine Microbiology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Restricted to junior or senior science majors or graduate students, with permission of the instructor.  Seminar class focuses on the primary research literature.  Physiology of marine microorganisms, microbial diversity and ecology of the marine environment, biogeochemical processes catalyzed by marine microorganisms.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC444
classes.subtitle: Marine Phytoplankton.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Restricted to junior or senior science majors or graduate students, with permission of the instructor.  Seminar class focuses on the primary research literature.  Physiology of marine microorganisms, microbial diversity and ecology of the marine environment, biogeochemical processes catalyzed by marine microorganisms.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC444
classes.subtitle: Marine Phytoplankton.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. For junior and senior science majors or graduate students. Biology of marine photosynthetic protists and cyanobacteria. Phytoplankton evolution, biodiversity, structure, function, biogeochemical cycles and genomics. Harmful algal blooms, commercial products, and climate change. Three lecture/practical session hours per week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�444, BIOL�456.

classes.title: MASC445
classes.subtitle: Marine Invertebrate Biology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. For junior and senior science majors or graduate students. Biology of marine photosynthetic protists and cyanobacteria. Phytoplankton evolution, biodiversity, structure, function, biogeochemical cycles and genomics. Harmful algal blooms, commercial products, and climate change. Three lecture/practical session hours per week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�444, BIOL�456.

classes.title: MASC445
classes.subtitle: Marine Invertebrate Biology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: See BIOL�475 for description.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC446
classes.subtitle: Marine Microbial Symbioses: Exploring How Microbial Interactions Affect Ecosystems and Human Health.  3 Credits.
classes.description: See BIOL�475 for description.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC446
classes.subtitle: Marine Microbial Symbioses: Exploring How Microbial Interactions Affect Ecosystems and Human Health.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Course material covers host-microbe and microbe-microbe interactions found in marine ecosystems, including beneficial and parasitic relationships among viruses, microbes, marine animals, and humans. Limited to upper-level undergraduate science majors and graduate students.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�452.

classes.title: MASC447
classes.subtitle: Microbial Ecological Genomics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Course material covers host-microbe and microbe-microbe interactions found in marine ecosystems, including beneficial and parasitic relationships among viruses, microbes, marine animals, and humans. Limited to upper-level undergraduate science majors and graduate students.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�452.

classes.title: MASC447
classes.subtitle: Microbial Ecological Genomics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. For junior and senior science majors and graduate students. Active learning class focused on sequencing and bioinformatic analysis of microbial genomes to identify their ecological function. Topics include sequencing technologies, genome assembly and analysis, command line, bioinformatic tools, and genes mediating microbial physiology and metabolism in natural ecosystems.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC448
classes.subtitle: Coastal and Estuarine Ecology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. For junior and senior science majors and graduate students. Active learning class focused on sequencing and bioinformatic analysis of microbial genomes to identify their ecological function. Topics include sequencing technologies, genome assembly and analysis, command line, bioinformatic tools, and genes mediating microbial physiology and metabolism in natural ecosystems.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC448
classes.subtitle: Coastal and Estuarine Ecology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: A field-intensive study of the ecology of marine organisms and their interactions with their environment, including commercially important organisms. Laboratory/recitation/field work is included and contributes two credit hours to the course.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102 and MATH�231.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�448.

classes.title: MASC450
classes.subtitle: Biogeochemical Processes.  4 Credits.
classes.description: A field-intensive study of the ecology of marine organisms and their interactions with their environment, including commercially important organisms. Laboratory/recitation/field work is included and contributes two credit hours to the course.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102 and MATH�231.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�448.

classes.title: MASC450
classes.subtitle: Biogeochemical Processes.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of chemistry, biology, and geology are applied to analysis of the fate and transport of materials in environmental systems, with an emphasis on those materials that form the most significant cycles. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�231, and PHYS�114 or 118; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�450, GEOL�450.

classes.title: MASC455
classes.subtitle: Geochemistry.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Principles of chemistry, biology, and geology are applied to analysis of the fate and transport of materials in environmental systems, with an emphasis on those materials that form the most significant cycles. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�231, and PHYS�114 or 118; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�450, GEOL�450.

classes.title: MASC455
classes.subtitle: Geochemistry.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, one introductory geology course. Introduction to the application of chemical principles to geological problems. Topics include thermodynamics, kinetics, and isotope geochemistry. Previously offered as GEOL 512/MASC 553.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102 and MATH�231; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Gen Ed: QI.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�405.

classes.title: MASC460
classes.subtitle: Fluid Dynamics of the Environment.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, one introductory geology course. Introduction to the application of chemical principles to geological problems. Topics include thermodynamics, kinetics, and isotope geochemistry. Previously offered as GEOL 512/MASC 553.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102 and MATH�231; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Gen Ed: QI.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�405.

classes.title: MASC460
classes.subtitle: Fluid Dynamics of the Environment.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Principles and applications of fluid dynamics to flows of air and water in the natural environment. Conservation of momentum, mass, and energy applied to lakes, rivers, estuaries, and the coastal ocean. Dimensional analysis and scaling emphasized to promote problem-solving skills.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�232; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC470
classes.subtitle: Estuarine and Coastal Marine Science.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Principles and applications of fluid dynamics to flows of air and water in the natural environment. Conservation of momentum, mass, and energy applied to lakes, rivers, estuaries, and the coastal ocean. Dimensional analysis and scaling emphasized to promote problem-solving skills.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�232; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC470
classes.subtitle: Estuarine and Coastal Marine Science.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduate students should take ENEC�222 or have permission of the instructor. Introduction to estuarine environments: geomorphology, physical circulation, nutrient loading, primary and secondary production, carbon and nitrogen cycling, benthic processes and sedimentation. Considers human impacts on coastal systems, emphasizing North Carolina estuaries.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC471
classes.subtitle: Human Impacts on Estuarine Ecosystems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduate students should take ENEC�222 or have permission of the instructor. Introduction to estuarine environments: geomorphology, physical circulation, nutrient loading, primary and secondary production, carbon and nitrogen cycling, benthic processes and sedimentation. Considers human impacts on coastal systems, emphasizing North Carolina estuaries.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC471
classes.subtitle: Human Impacts on Estuarine Ecosystems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: A cohesive examination of the human impacts on biological processes in estuarine ecosystems. Laboratory/recitation/field work is included and contributes two credit hours to the course.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102 and MATH�231.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�471.

classes.title: MASC472
classes.subtitle: Barrier Island Ecology and Geology.  6 Credits.
classes.description: A cohesive examination of the human impacts on biological processes in estuarine ecosystems. Laboratory/recitation/field work is included and contributes two credit hours to the course.Requisites: Prerequisites, CHEM�102 and MATH�231.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENEC�471.

classes.title: MASC472
classes.subtitle: Barrier Island Ecology and Geology.  6 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, one introductory geology course. An integration of barrier island plant and animal ecology within the context of physical processes and geomorphological change. Emphasis on management and impact of human interference with natural processes.Gen Ed: PL, EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC473
classes.subtitle: The Changing Coasts of Carolina.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, one introductory geology course. An integration of barrier island plant and animal ecology within the context of physical processes and geomorphological change. Emphasis on management and impact of human interference with natural processes.Gen Ed: PL, EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC473
classes.subtitle: The Changing Coasts of Carolina.  3 Credits.
classes.description: A rigorous combination of field work, lab work, and colorful, original contemporary writing on the natural world will help tell the story of our many, evolving North Carolina coasts. Combining marine science and the creative literary arts, this immersive course will explore issues of change over many eras. This combination of social, cultural, and scientific observation will lead to imaginatively constructed, well-written non-fiction reportage about one of North America's most productive, compelling, and challenging regions.Gen Ed: CI, EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENGL�473.

classes.title: MASC480
classes.subtitle: Modeling of Marine and Earth Systems.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: A rigorous combination of field work, lab work, and colorful, original contemporary writing on the natural world will help tell the story of our many, evolving North Carolina coasts. Combining marine science and the creative literary arts, this immersive course will explore issues of change over many eras. This combination of social, cultural, and scientific observation will lead to imaginatively constructed, well-written non-fiction reportage about one of North America's most productive, compelling, and challenging regions.Gen Ed: CI, EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENGL�473.

classes.title: MASC480
classes.subtitle: Modeling of Marine and Earth Systems.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: Mathematical modeling of dynamic systems, linear and nonlinear. The fundamental budget equation. Case studies in modeling transport, biogeochemical processes, population dynamics. Analytical and numerical techniques; chaos theory; fractal geometry.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�232; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�480, ENVR�480.

classes.title: MASC483
classes.subtitle: Geologic and Oceanographic Applications of Geographical Information Systems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Mathematical modeling of dynamic systems, linear and nonlinear. The fundamental budget equation. Case studies in modeling transport, biogeochemical processes, population dynamics. Analytical and numerical techniques; chaos theory; fractal geometry.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�232; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�480, ENVR�480.

classes.title: MASC483
classes.subtitle: Geologic and Oceanographic Applications of Geographical Information Systems.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, four GEOL courses or permission of the instructor. Focus is on applying GIS concepts and techniques to mining and petroleum geology, resource assessment, hydrogeology, coastal and marine geology, physical oceanography, engineering geology, and a geologic perspective on land use. Three lecture and two laboratory hours a week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�483.

classes.title: MASC490
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Sciences for Undergraduates and Graduates.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: Required preparation, four GEOL courses or permission of the instructor. Focus is on applying GIS concepts and techniques to mining and petroleum geology, resource assessment, hydrogeology, coastal and marine geology, physical oceanography, engineering geology, and a geologic perspective on land use. Three lecture and two laboratory hours a week.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�483.

classes.title: MASC490
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Sciences for Undergraduates and Graduates.  1-3 Credits.
classes.description: Directed readings, laboratory, and/or field study of marine science topics not covered in scheduled courses.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 12 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC503
classes.subtitle: Marine Geology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Directed readings, laboratory, and/or field study of marine science topics not covered in scheduled courses.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 12 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC503
classes.subtitle: Marine Geology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Investigates formation of the oceans, plate tectonics, carbonate reefs and platforms, sediment transport from the land to deep-sea fans, glacial-marine geology, marine records of changes in sea level and climate, and the evolution of barrier islands, estuaries, and deltas. Mandatory weekend field trip to the Southern Outer Banks.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�503.

classes.title: MASC504
classes.subtitle: Biological Oceanography.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Investigates formation of the oceans, plate tectonics, carbonate reefs and platforms, sediment transport from the land to deep-sea fans, glacial-marine geology, marine records of changes in sea level and climate, and the evolution of barrier islands, estuaries, and deltas. Mandatory weekend field trip to the Southern Outer Banks.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�503.

classes.title: MASC504
classes.subtitle: Biological Oceanography.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Marine ecosystem processes pertaining to the structure, function, and ecological interactions of biological communities; management of biological resources; taxonomy and natural history of pelagic and benthic marine organisms. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week. Two mandatory weekend fieldtrips.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�657, ENVR�520.

classes.title: MASC505
classes.subtitle: Chemical Oceanography.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Marine ecosystem processes pertaining to the structure, function, and ecological interactions of biological communities; management of biological resources; taxonomy and natural history of pelagic and benthic marine organisms. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week. Two mandatory weekend fieldtrips.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�657, ENVR�520.

classes.title: MASC505
classes.subtitle: Chemical Oceanography.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Graduate students only; undergraduates must have permission of the instructor. Overview of chemical processes in the ocean. Topics include physical chemistry of seawater, major element cycles, hydrothermal vents, geochemical tracers, air-sea gas exchange, particle transport, sedimentary processes, and marine organic geochemistry. Three lecture and two recitation hours per week.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENVR�505, GEOL�505.

classes.title: MASC506
classes.subtitle: Physical Oceanography.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Graduate students only; undergraduates must have permission of the instructor. Overview of chemical processes in the ocean. Topics include physical chemistry of seawater, major element cycles, hydrothermal vents, geochemical tracers, air-sea gas exchange, particle transport, sedimentary processes, and marine organic geochemistry. Three lecture and two recitation hours per week.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENVR�505, GEOL�505.

classes.title: MASC506
classes.subtitle: Physical Oceanography.  4 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Descriptive oceanography, large-scale wind-driven and thermohaline circulations, ocean dynamics, regional and nearshore/estuarine physical processes, waves, tides. Three lecture and one recitation hour per week.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�506.

classes.title: MASC550
classes.subtitle: Biogeochemical Cycling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Descriptive oceanography, large-scale wind-driven and thermohaline circulations, ocean dynamics, regional and nearshore/estuarine physical processes, waves, tides. Three lecture and one recitation hour per week.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�506.

classes.title: MASC550
classes.subtitle: Biogeochemical Cycling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Biogeochemical cycling explores interfaces of marine, aquatic, atmospheric, and geological sciences emphasizing processes controlling chemical distributions in sediments, fresh and salt water, the atmosphere, and fluxes among these reservoirs.Requisites: Prerequisites, ENVR�421; GEOL�405, 436, 655; MASC�440, 505; or permission of the instructor.Gen Ed: PL, CI.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�550.

classes.title: MASC552
classes.subtitle: Organic Geochemistry.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Biogeochemical cycling explores interfaces of marine, aquatic, atmospheric, and geological sciences emphasizing processes controlling chemical distributions in sediments, fresh and salt water, the atmosphere, and fluxes among these reservoirs.Requisites: Prerequisites, ENVR�421; GEOL�405, 436, 655; MASC�440, 505; or permission of the instructor.Gen Ed: PL, CI.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�550.

classes.title: MASC552
classes.subtitle: Organic Geochemistry.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, CHEM�261 or MASC�505, and one additional ENVR, GEOL, or MASC course above 400. Sources, transformations, and fate of natural organic matter in marine environments. Emphasis on interplay of chemical, biological, and physical processes that affect organic matter composition, distribution, and turnover.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�552, ENVR�552.

classes.title: MASC560
classes.subtitle: Fluid Dynamics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, CHEM�261 or MASC�505, and one additional ENVR, GEOL, or MASC course above 400. Sources, transformations, and fate of natural organic matter in marine environments. Emphasis on interplay of chemical, biological, and physical processes that affect organic matter composition, distribution, and turnover.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�552, ENVR�552.

classes.title: MASC560
classes.subtitle: Fluid Dynamics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: The physical properties of fluids, kinematics, governing equations, viscous incompressible flow, vorticity dynamics, boundary layers, irrotational incompressible flow.Requisites: Prerequisite, PHYS�401; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENVR�452, GEOL�560, PHYS�660.

classes.title: MASC561
classes.subtitle: Time Series and Spatial Data Analysis.  3 Credits.
classes.description: The physical properties of fluids, kinematics, governing equations, viscous incompressible flow, vorticity dynamics, boundary layers, irrotational incompressible flow.Requisites: Prerequisite, PHYS�401; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ENVR�452, GEOL�560, PHYS�660.

classes.title: MASC561
classes.subtitle: Time Series and Spatial Data Analysis.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Three components: statistics and probability, time series analysis, and spatial data analysis. Harmonic analysis, nonparametric spectral estimation, filtering, objective analysis, empirical orthogonal functions.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�233; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC562
classes.subtitle: Turbulent Boundary Layers.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Three components: statistics and probability, time series analysis, and spatial data analysis. Harmonic analysis, nonparametric spectral estimation, filtering, objective analysis, empirical orthogonal functions.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�233; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC562
classes.subtitle: Turbulent Boundary Layers.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Turbulence and transport in near-bottom boundary regions. Turbulence and mixing theory in boundary layers. Field deployment and recovery of turbulence measuring instruments. Data analysis from turbulence measurements.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or 560; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC563
classes.subtitle: Descriptive Physical Oceanography.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Turbulence and transport in near-bottom boundary regions. Turbulence and mixing theory in boundary layers. Field deployment and recovery of turbulence measuring instruments. Data analysis from turbulence measurements.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or 560; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: PL, QI.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC563
classes.subtitle: Descriptive Physical Oceanography.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Observed structure of the large-scale and mesoscale ocean circulation and its variability, based on modern observations. In-situ and remote sensing techniques, hydrographic structure, circulation patterns, ocean-atmosphere interactions.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�563.

classes.title: MASC705
classes.subtitle: How to Give a Seminar.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Observed structure of the large-scale and mesoscale ocean circulation and its variability, based on modern observations. In-situ and remote sensing techniques, hydrographic structure, circulation patterns, ocean-atmosphere interactions.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Gen Ed: PL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�563.

classes.title: MASC705
classes.subtitle: How to Give a Seminar.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Discussion of methods and strategies for giving effective technical presentations. Topics will include seminar structure, use of visual aids, personal and professional presentation, and responding to questions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC706
classes.subtitle: Student Interdisciplinary Seminar.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Discussion of methods and strategies for giving effective technical presentations. Topics will include seminar structure, use of visual aids, personal and professional presentation, and responding to questions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC706
classes.subtitle: Student Interdisciplinary Seminar.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Marine Sciences graduate students will prepare and present a seminar on an interdisciplinary topic from contemporary research in marine systems.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�705.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC730
classes.subtitle: Advanced Coastal Environmental Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Marine Sciences graduate students will prepare and present a seminar on an interdisciplinary topic from contemporary research in marine systems.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�705.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC730
classes.subtitle: Advanced Coastal Environmental Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Focuses on biological-physical couplings that shape coastal environments (i.e. coastal 'ecomorphodynamics') and determine how these environments change with climate and land use. Environments include: barrier islands, open ocean coastlines, and tidal wetlands. Grading based on presentations, participation, and a research proposal.Requisites: Prerequisites, GEOL�417, 502, or 503; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�710, ENEC�710.

classes.title: MASC741
classes.subtitle: Seminar in Marine Biology.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Focuses on biological-physical couplings that shape coastal environments (i.e. coastal 'ecomorphodynamics') and determine how these environments change with climate and land use. Environments include: barrier islands, open ocean coastlines, and tidal wetlands. Grading based on presentations, participation, and a research proposal.Requisites: Prerequisites, GEOL�417, 502, or 503; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: GEOL�710, ENEC�710.

classes.title: MASC741
classes.subtitle: Seminar in Marine Biology.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Discussion of selected literature in the field of marine biology, ecology, and evolution.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC742
classes.subtitle: Molecular Population Biology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Discussion of selected literature in the field of marine biology, ecology, and evolution.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC742
classes.subtitle: Molecular Population Biology.  4 Credits.
classes.description: Hands-on training, experience, and discussion of the application of molecular genetic tools to questions of ecology, evolution, systematics, and conservation.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOL�471; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�758.

classes.title: MASC750
classes.subtitle: Modeling Diagenetic Processes.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Hands-on training, experience, and discussion of the application of molecular genetic tools to questions of ecology, evolution, systematics, and conservation.Requisites: Prerequisite, BIOL�471; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: BIOL�758.

classes.title: MASC750
classes.subtitle: Modeling Diagenetic Processes.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An introduction to the theory and application of modeling biogeochemical processes in sediments. Diagenetic theory, numerical techniques, and examples of recently developed sediment models. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�480; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC761
classes.subtitle: Geophysical Fluid Dynamics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: An introduction to the theory and application of modeling biogeochemical processes in sediments. Diagenetic theory, numerical techniques, and examples of recently developed sediment models. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�480; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC761
classes.subtitle: Geophysical Fluid Dynamics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Momentum equations in a rotating reference frame, vorticity, potential vorticity, circulation, the shallow water model, Rossby and Kelvin waves, the Ekman layer. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�560 or MATH�528; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC762
classes.subtitle: Ocean Circulation Theory.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Momentum equations in a rotating reference frame, vorticity, potential vorticity, circulation, the shallow water model, Rossby and Kelvin waves, the Ekman layer. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�560 or MATH�528; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC762
classes.subtitle: Ocean Circulation Theory.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Theories, models of large-scale dynamics of ocean circulation. Potential vorticity, quasi-geostrophy, instabilities.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or 560, or MATH�529; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC763
classes.subtitle: Coastal Circulation.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Theories, models of large-scale dynamics of ocean circulation. Potential vorticity, quasi-geostrophy, instabilities.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or 560, or MATH�529; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC763
classes.subtitle: Coastal Circulation.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Dynamics of the coastal ocean. Shallow water equations, boundary layer and long wave theory, wind driven circulation, fronts, estuaries.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or 560, or MATH�529; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC764
classes.subtitle: Ocean Circulation Modeling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Dynamics of the coastal ocean. Shallow water equations, boundary layer and long wave theory, wind driven circulation, fronts, estuaries.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or 560, or MATH�529; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC764
classes.subtitle: Ocean Circulation Modeling.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Computational methods used in modeling oceanic circulation. Numerical solution of equations governing mass, momentum, and energy equations.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or MATH�529; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC765
classes.subtitle: Small-Scale Physics of the Ocean.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Computational methods used in modeling oceanic circulation. Numerical solution of equations governing mass, momentum, and energy equations.Requisites: Prerequisite, MASC�506 or MATH�529; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC765
classes.subtitle: Small-Scale Physics of the Ocean.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Physics of sub-mesoscale processes in the ocean. Nonequilibrium thermodynamics. Air-sea interaction. Mixing in the ocean boundary layer, convection, double diffusion. Near-inertial and high frequency internal waves. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, MASC�506 and 560.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC781
classes.subtitle: Numerical ODE/PDE, I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Physics of sub-mesoscale processes in the ocean. Nonequilibrium thermodynamics. Air-sea interaction. Mixing in the ocean boundary layer, convection, double diffusion. Near-inertial and high frequency internal waves. Three lecture hours a week.Requisites: Prerequisites, MASC�506 and 560.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC781
classes.subtitle: Numerical ODE/PDE, I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Single, multistep methods for ODEs: stability regions, the root condition; stiff systems, backward difference formulas; two-point BVPs; stability theory; finite difference methods for linear advection diffusion equations.Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�661 and 662.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�761, ENVR�761.

classes.title: MASC782
classes.subtitle: Numerical ODE/PDE, II.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Single, multistep methods for ODEs: stability regions, the root condition; stiff systems, backward difference formulas; two-point BVPs; stability theory; finite difference methods for linear advection diffusion equations.Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�661 and 662.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�761, ENVR�761.

classes.title: MASC782
classes.subtitle: Numerical ODE/PDE, II.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Elliptic equation methods (finite differences, elements, integral equations); hyperbolic conservation law methods (Lax-Fiedrich, characteristics, entropy condition, shock tracking/capturing); spectral, pseudo-spectral methods; particle methods, fast summation, fast multipole/vortex methods.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�761.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�762, ENVR�762.

classes.title: MASC783
classes.subtitle: Mathematical Modeling I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Elliptic equation methods (finite differences, elements, integral equations); hyperbolic conservation law methods (Lax-Fiedrich, characteristics, entropy condition, shock tracking/capturing); spectral, pseudo-spectral methods; particle methods, fast summation, fast multipole/vortex methods.Requisites: Prerequisite, MATH�761.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�762, ENVR�762.

classes.title: MASC783
classes.subtitle: Mathematical Modeling I.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Nondimensionalization and identification of leading order physical effects with respect to relevant scales and phenomena; derivation of classical models of fluid mechanics (lubrication, slender filament, thin films, Stokes flow); derivation of weakly nonlinear envelope equations. Fall.Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�661, 662, 668, and 669.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�768, ENVR�763.

classes.title: MASC784
classes.subtitle: Mathematical Modeling II.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Nondimensionalization and identification of leading order physical effects with respect to relevant scales and phenomena; derivation of classical models of fluid mechanics (lubrication, slender filament, thin films, Stokes flow); derivation of weakly nonlinear envelope equations. Fall.Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�661, 662, 668, and 669.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�768, ENVR�763.

classes.title: MASC784
classes.subtitle: Mathematical Modeling II.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Current models in science and technology: topics ranging from material science applications (e.g., flow of polymers and LCPs); geophysical applications (e.g., ocean circulation, quasi-geostrophic models, atmospheric vortices).Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�661, 662, 668, and 669.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�769, ENVR�764.

classes.title: MASC799
classes.subtitle: Experimental Graduate.  1-9 Credits.
classes.description: Current models in science and technology: topics ranging from material science applications (e.g., flow of polymers and LCPs); geophysical applications (e.g., ocean circulation, quasi-geostrophic models, atmospheric vortices).Requisites: Prerequisites, MATH�661, 662, 668, and 669.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: MATH�769, ENVR�764.

classes.title: MASC799
classes.subtitle: Experimental Graduate.  1-9 Credits.
classes.description: Experimental graduate level courses as offered by the Department.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 1 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Marine Geology.  1-9 Credits.

classes.description: Special topics courses in Marine Geology as offered by Department.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 1 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Biological Oceanography.  1-9 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics courses in Marine Geology as offered by Department.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 1 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Biological Oceanography.  1-9 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics courses in Biological Oceanography as offered by Department.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 1 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: MASC895
classes.subtitle: Special Topics in Physical Oceanography.  1-9 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics courses in Biological Oceanography as offered by Department.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 1 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.
